issues.title: Update existing registrations?
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
If the AEGIS RFC removed the IANA registrations for 

TLS_AEGIS_256_SHA512
TLS_AEGIS_128L_SHA256

it might be a good idea to uodate the reference in IANA to point to this document.

comments.author: jedisct1
comments.body:
Hi John,

IANA didn't remove the code points; they point to the previous revision of the AEGIS draft.

What we can do is finish a first version of this document, propose it to the TLS WG, and if it is accepted, ask IANA to update them.

comments.author: jedisct1
comments.body:
A first version of the document can be seen here: https://jedisct1.github.io/draft-denis-tls-aegis/draft-denis-tls-aegis.html

Your input is more that welcome.

issues.title: Are examples useful?
issues.author: jedisct1
issues.body:
Adding AEGIS to existing TLS libraries shouldn't be difficult.

Still, there are differences with other cipher suites:

- The nonce sizes (128 and 256 bits), whereas other ciphers use a 96 bit nonce, and implementations may be designed around that assumption.
- Usage of SHA512 for key derivation, so secrets are bigger too.

Making these differences obvious was one of the goals of having these examples.

But maybe they are not necessary, especially the ones about nonce computation.

comments.author: samuel-lucas6
comments.body: They probably aren't necessary, but I think we can keep them in unless we're told to remove them.

comments.author: jedisct1
comments.body: Sounds good, especially now that the nonce derivation examples are gone.

issues.title: Document when to use the different variants of the given security level
issues.author: jedisct1
issues.body:
This is addressed in the original AEGIS draft, but it could be good to have this in the operational considerations section of that draft as well.

Essentially: security properties are the same and implementations should pick the fastest option for the hardware they run on.

issues.title: Should nonce_len be in bits?
issues.author: samuel-lucas6
issues.body:
In Sections 4/5, should `nonce_len` be in bits since the `ZeroPad()` function takes the second parameter in bits?

> nonce_len: the AEGIS nonce length, either 16 or 32, depending on the chosen AEAD algorithm.
> 
> A 48-bit mask is computed as follows:
> 
> mask = Stream(48, sn_key, ZeroPad(ciphertext[0..16], nonce_len))

From the AEGIS draft:

> ZeroPad(x, n): padding operation. Trailing zeros are concatenated to x until the total length is a multiple of n bits.

comments.author: jedisct1
comments.body: Good catch! Yes, having them in bits totally makes sense.

pulls.title: Use bits, not bytes for the length in Stream() function
pulls.author: jedisct1
pulls.body: This also improves clarity and consistency, as the mask is previously defined as "a 48-bit mask".

pulls.title: Remove the examples on nonce derivation
pulls.author: jedisct1
pulls.body:
This is just an XOR operation.

The intent was to highlight the fact that nonce sizes in AEGIS differ from other AEADs, and that the code responsible for nonce derivation was likely affected in implementations.

But that can be mentioned in the rest of the document.

Previous examples are enough to show that AEGIS uses 128-bit and 256-bit nonces.

pulls.title: nonce_len should be in bits
pulls.author: jedisct1
pulls.body:
And the unit was explicitly added for more clarity.

Fixes #6

reviews.author: samuel-lucas6
reviews.body: Should the `nonce_len` in Section A.2 be updated to bits too? Otherwise, looks good.
